resources.string: Gardenizer
My Garden
picture of wildflowers

It's winter! 
Don't forget to remove snow from roofs, plants and paths 
do the winter cut on your fruit trees
start sowing tomatos, bell pepper and annual summerflowers on your window sill 
if you have a nesting box outside: check if it is clean and has enough birdseed 
your compost could do with a good stir and sieving

It is still cooooold... 
 think about the poor little starving birds and put birdseeds into the nesting boxes 
now it is time for prepare the soil for the closer getting garden season 
if the soil is not deeply frozen you can prepare the first plant holes for March and April 
if you have italian grape-vine now is the time to trim it!

Spring is coming! Or is it really? 
The ground and soil is slowly starting to warm up, you can start preparing the first sowing like cauliflower, parsley and parsnips 
Let early potatoes bud on your window sill 
prepare the soil in your potatoe bed 
fertilise your fruit trees and 
put up some insect hotels for some buzzing and action in spring and summer!

Sun! Rain! Hail! Frost! 
it's time to sow your potatoes into the prepared soil! 
have a look at your herbs: now is the time to cut, plant or sow your thyme, salvia, rosemary, oregano and mint 
if you plan on having (more) fruit trees or bushes: now is the time them

Last but not least...
It's May after all! Not long and you can buy and maybe pick your first strawberries! 
One vegetable which is now ready to be picked and prepared is rhubarb, perfect for compot, cake or chutney. 
put the potatoes into the wonderfully prepared bed, it is very important to pile the soil very well, don't let the potatoes get ruined by the sun 
keep your plants safe from snails, which are now coming out, hungry for freshly growing vegetables... 
keep all plants humid

Strawberry paradise! 
But before your start picking and eating there is a bit of work to do: 
start cultivating salad 
pick some elderberry blossoms and make some yummy syrup 
get that weed out of the ground before its seeds are getting ripe 
vegetables to be planted in june: salad, leek, broccoli, herb, sellerie, courgettes (however better results maybe achieved when planting in MAY! 
the perennial herbs are getting high, you should consider propping them so that they don't collaps

Summer is finally there! 
enjoy harvesting the first vegetables and fruit and then don't forget to dung the harvested beds 
if your weed beds are exploding crop them and dry some weed. Or freeze it! 
young fruit trees need to be kept free from gras 
summercut on your sweet cherry trees 
cut your perennial herbs and roses to stimulate more blossoms 
pick a bunch of flowers and enjoy them on your coffee table

And apple a day... 
time to pick your first apples, plums and summer pears 
prepare a new strawberry field for next year 
time to harvest rose hips - try them in jam for example! 
keep the compost moist 
sow some winter herbs 
if it's a hot and dry summer put up a bird bath

Prepare for the colder days 
harvest your potatoes, you'll be surprised how much you get out of one single planted potatoe! 
onions should be ready as well 
if you're lucky you have some raspberries waiting for you 
prepare a new bed for perennial herbs 
get out the tulip bulbs which will double after a year and divide them. Then plant them in fresh soil. 
TIPP: if you plant them within a plastic flower pot they will be safe from getting eaten by root voles or other animals and it will be easy for you to find them next autumn.

Autumn is coming! 
now the sometimes rough but at the same time cosy season is starting 
there is still something to harvest like walnuts and other nuts, some potatoes might still be there 
try to collect snail eggs and get rid of them 
 gather leaves and put it on the compost 
now is the time to plant roses and tulip bulbs 
start putting sensitive plants in pots inside

BRRRRRRRRR 
prepare your harvested vegetable beds for winter 
first frost might be coming so pour the water out of watering cans and rain barrels 
clean and put away your gardening tools 
plant rhubarb now 
Winter cut for fruit trees 
put away your garden chairs and tables 
protect sensitive plants from frost

Save the birds! 
not much active gardening work to do, BUT 
you can plan for next year: which plants would you like to plant? 
put up some new high beds 
enjoy winter, bake some cookies and go to a bunch of x-mas markets 
(oh, and don't forget to buy lots of presents)
Bring colour into your garden \n
